instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1989: What is A1989? A1989 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2018, 2019 with EMC 3124, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00850..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> unable to start investigating due to USB C Port fluctuation
threads.message:
Hi Community,

got a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> that shows a strange behaviour while powering up.

USB C Port 1 is stable 5 V at 0,170A draw
USB C Port 2 5V with fluctuating draw jumping from 0,47A down to 0,045A and repeating
USB C Port 3 5V with fluctuating draw jumping from 0,47A down to 0,045A and repeating
USB C Port 4 5V with fluctuating draw jumping from 0,47A down to 0,045A and repeating including rebooting of port

With the thermal camera i was able to identify one <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> which is roughly 20 degrees warmer then the threee other ones, reading roughly 50 degrees C.

Also I have identified ELC180 chip to be also pulsing when USB is plugged in.
Video below:

Board is perfectly fine, no liquid spill or any visible damage identified so far.

I have not found any advice on an identical behaviour so far, and am looking forward for your advice

[MEDIA=youtube]OR1hz4NhDtc[/MEDIA]

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> unable to start investigating due to USB C Port fluctuation
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Any history available?

Post voltage and diode mode readings on the 4 LDO lines of each <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip.
Be aware, 1V1 LDO BMC should appear only on the powered port.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> unable to start investigating due to USB C Port fluctuation
threads.message:
Laptop was purchased as broken, so unclear what happened.
First initial readings attached:

UB300
LDO BMC 0
LDOD 1,1 to 3,9 flucuating
LDOA 1,1 to 1,8 fluctuating
PP3V3 UPC TA LDO 3,1 V

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>
LDO BMC 0
LDOD 1,7 V
LDOA 1,8
PP3V3 UPC TA LDO 3,2 V

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
LDO BMC 0
LDOD 1,7 V
LDOA 1,8
PP3V3 UPC TA LDO 3,2 V

UB400
LDO BMC 0
LDOD 1,7V
LDOA 1,7V
PP3V3 UPC TA LDO 3,3 V


Actually I´m measuring a short on CB300 and CB400, <CAPACITOR>C3100</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C3200</CAPACITOR>  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>

Can u help me out on where to get the diode measured please?
